As for those with the most, they have nineteen, excluding the two pure and one sex faculty.
This is the sixth section on determining the maximum number of faculties one can possess.
The treatise states: Those with the most can possess nineteen.
This explains the first two lines.
The maximum is nineteen.
Those with two sex organs must be ordinary beings in the desire realm.
If they have not lost the four faculties of eye, etc.,
they must have the five of faith, etc., since they have not cut off good roots.
Those with two sex organs cannot be free from desire, so they definitely possess the five feelings.
Their body, life, and mind faculties must also be present, so they have nineteen.
Those with two sex organs cannot enter the holy path, excluding the three pure faculties.
The two bonds refer to the bond of association and the bond of objects.
Are there any more that possess nineteen?
This is the question.
The noble one who has not yet abandoned desire... up to... because there are no two genders.
This is the answer.
It explains the two sentences below.
This explanation means that the noble one who has not yet abandoned desire may at most possess nineteen.
According to circumstances, two pure [roots] are excluded,
and one gender is excluded.
Either the female or male root is excluded.
Because the noble ones have no two genders, they do not possess twenty.
Moreover, the correct explanation says:
The one gender refers to
those who have no two genders or no gender, because they do not attain the noble Dharma. Since the treatise says that those who have no gender do not attain the noble Dharma,
it is clear that the male and female roots must be attained as one. How can one gradually abandon them and enter the noble path?
This difficulty is resolved as explained above.
